channel.title: Css
channel.description:
What's easyer?
Writing a theme from scratch or Using Photoshop to create the theme
At the minute im having trouble with Padding and Margin elements..

item.title: Css
item.dc:creator: @EclipseRuins EclipseRuins
item.description:
@EclipseRuins wrote:

I would much recommend using CSS, it teaches you a lot of new stuff, and isn’t very hard to learn if you need any help with some CSS questions just feel free to PM me.

Read full topic

item.title: Css
item.dc:creator: @_s11 s1gma
item.description:
@_s11 wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:12, topic:426177”][quote author=justaguy link=topic=528868.msg3860220#msg3860220 date=1324610849]

People who can call themselves web developers and designers dont rely on WYSIWYG editors.

Web designers do. Web developers don’t.

Designers should not either. It is acceptable to have templates created and such using Photoshop and the like, but limiting their design on an actual webpage to a WYSIWYG editor is stupid.

It’s stupid, but it’s the common occurence. Besides, to the designers, a WYSIWYG is all they need because, what they see in the program, is what other people will see on their browsers (or so they think).

I’m a web developer, because I prefer the programming aspect over the “fluff”.

http://www.webdevelopersnotes.com/design/wysiwyg_html_editors_advantages_disadvantages.php3 (look at disadvantages)
http://css.dzone.com/news/wysi-not-wyg-living-their-lies

Front-end developers dont just use simple HTML and CSS anymore, a lot more of them are now working professionally with Javascript. Not to mention Javascript is now a very important component of making websites, so the ‘fluff’ is very important as well.
[/quote]

Most web designers use flash, since they can still use a WYSIWYG editor (Dreamweaver).[/quote]most web designers aren’t complete morons so i suggest you stop painting them as complete morons. flash is almost completely unofficially deprecated and using WYSIWYG editors can cause havoc when it comes to displaying on small (or extensively large) displays, which with the advent of smartphones/tablets/netbooks/texas-sized-monitors are frequently used. any web designer worth anyone’s time will probably either do everything by hand or use photoshop for templating.

Read full topic

item.title: Css
item.dc:creator: @Kryptix Kryptix
item.description:
@Kryptix wrote:

[quote=“Daginith, post:5, topic:426177”]i suggest you use CSS yourself, its more custom, and it helps you be a better coder. u said u had issues with the padding and margins?

 
test {
   padding-top: 0px;
   padding-left: 0px;
   padding-right: 0px;
   padding-bottom: 0px;
   margin: 0px 0px 0px 0px;
}

^^im not sure thats what u need, but its the padding and margin codes, lol[/quote]

* { margin: 0px; padding: 0px; }

Read full topic

item.title: Css
item.dc:creator: @justaguy justaguy
item.description:
@justaguy wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:12, topic:426177”][quote author=justaguy link=topic=528868.msg3860220#msg3860220 date=1324610849]

People who can call themselves web developers and designers dont rely on WYSIWYG editors.

Web designers do. Web developers don’t.

Designers should not either. It is acceptable to have templates created and such using Photoshop and the like, but limiting their design on an actual webpage to a WYSIWYG editor is stupid.

It’s stupid, but it’s the common occurence. Besides, to the designers, a WYSIWYG is all they need because, what they see in the program, is what other people will see on their browsers (or so they think).

I’m a web developer, because I prefer the programming aspect over the “fluff”.

http://www.webdevelopersnotes.com/design/wysiwyg_html_editors_advantages_disadvantages.php3 (look at disadvantages)
http://css.dzone.com/news/wysi-not-wyg-living-their-lies

Front-end developers dont just use simple HTML and CSS anymore, a lot more of them are now working professionally with Javascript. Not to mention Javascript is now a very important component of making websites, so the ‘fluff’ is very important as well.
[/quote]

Most web designers use flash, since they can still use a WYSIWYG editor (Dreamweaver).[/quote]

I have to disagree.
By looking at the magnitude of websites which even have flash used somewhere on the page, its pretty minimal. I think the only useful/popular use of flash lately has been for accessing the clipboard. I dont see very many websites using flash, especially when it comes to the display and design of the actual webpages.

Read full topic

People who can call themselves web developers and designers dont rely on WYSIWYG editors.

Web designers do. Web developers don’t.

Designers should not either. It is acceptable to have templates created and such using Photoshop and the like, but limiting their design on an actual webpage to a WYSIWYG editor is stupid.

It’s stupid, but it’s the common occurence. Besides, to the designers, a WYSIWYG is all they need because, what they see in the program, is what other people will see on their browsers (or so they think).

I’m a web developer, because I prefer the programming aspect over the “fluff”.
[/quote]

http://www.webdevelopersnotes.com/design/wysiwyg_html_editors_advantages_disadvantages.php3 (look at disadvantages)
http://css.dzone.com/news/wysi-not-wyg-living-their-lies

Front-end developers dont just use simple HTML and CSS anymore, a lot more of them are now working professionally with Javascript. Not to mention Javascript is now a very important component of making websites, so the ‘fluff’ is very important as well.[/quote]

Most web designers use flash, since they can still use a WYSIWYG editor (Dreamweaver).

item.description:

[quote=“Native^, post:3, topic:426177”]Photoshop can generate CSS?[/quote]Yea… I’m with you on that one… CSS is easy… You should probably do it yourself so you don’t have all the issues you could possibly run into with a code generator. Just a suggestion

http://www.w3schools.com/css/default.asp

item.title: Css
item.dc:creator: @Muroth Muroth
item.description:
@Muroth wrote:

While Photoshop does generate bits of CSS, it won’t be perfect. I create images and then just write the CSS from scratch, it’s much easier for me, and it keeps me organized.
